major.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: having very serious or worrying results
major.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: There is a major problem with parking in London.
The loss of their goalkeeper through injury was a major setback for the team.
He underwent major heart surgery recently.
It could have sparked a major confrontation.
major.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: very large or important, when compared to other things or people of a similar kind
major.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: There are two major political parties in the US.
The government’s major concern is with preventing road accidents.
Smoking is one of the major causes of cancer.
the major developments in computer technology
Britain played a major role in the negotiations.
major.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: This is major? You got me out of bed for this?
major.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a major key is based on a musical scale in which there are semitones between the third and fourth and the seventh and eighth notes
major.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: an officer of middle rank in the British or US army or Marines, or in the US air force
major.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: the main subject that a student studies at college or university
major.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: someone studying a particular subject as their main subject at college or university
major.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: very large or important when compared with other companies, countries, activities etc of a similar kind
major.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: a meeting of the seven major industrialized nations
The company is currently undergoing a major restructuring.
major.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The company’s major problem was its reliance on the big UK market.
There are no major safety concerns with this product.
major.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: a very important company in a particular industry
major.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: The majors are taking market share away from smaller companies.
